column11: Notes

"ėdmi" uses archaic ending (1st person sing.).
Nowadays "ėdu" (1st person sing.).

"akstinas" previously had a meaning "a sharp prick or goad for driving cattle". Nowadays "akstinas" means "motive, stimulus, urge, incentive".

There is though an adjective "aštrus" meaning "sharp".

"esti" is 3rd person sing.  
asmi - esmi (1st person), 
asi - esi (2nd person), 
asti - esti (3rd person) .

"ungurys" in Lithuanian means "eel" (fish). 

Knowing that "ahi" means snake or serpent there is a much closer word in Lith. "angis" (snake viper).

"eimi" uses archaic ending (1st person sing.).
Nowadays "einu" (1st person sing.) or "eiti" (infinit.).
Infinitive.

"ūgis" in Lithuanian means "height, tallness".
"augu" - "I grow"
vanduo is a noun and means "water".

"veržiu" is 1st person sing. 
"verži" - 2nd person sing.
"veržia" - 3rd person sing.
"veržti" - infinitive.
P.S. I provide these forms only if you decide to use infinitives. MW sometimes gives 1st person sing. forms, sometimes infinitives.

"irti" means "to row".
"arti" means "to plough".
eismė is an old Lithuanian word used in the XIX cent. and the beginning of XX century and means "the act of walking", "movement".
Same as above.

"kanku" is 1st person sing.
"kanki" - 2nd person sing.
"kanka" -3rd person sing.
"kakti"- infinitive.
Nowadays used only with prefixes.

"kinkau" is 1st person sing.
"kinkai" - 2nd person sing.
"kinko" -3rd person sing.
"kinkyti"- infinitive.
kušinu is 1st person sing and has a meaning of "to tease or irritate". It is rearly used.

"kupra" is a noun "hump, humback".
"kuprotas" is an adjective "hump-backed".

"kertu" is 1st person sing.
"kirsti"- infinitive.
In my humble opionion it would be better to use infinitives "karšti, plėšyti".

"gelbmi" has an archaic ending 1st person sing.
Nowadays "gelbėti" infinitive.
kraujas means "blood".
perku is 1st person sing.

"čiaudmi" is 1st person sing. and has an archaic ending "-mi".  
Nowadays "čiaudžiu" (1st pers.sing.), čiaudėti (infinit.).
Infinitive.

"gadijos" - looks like an archaic form of a noun. 
"žadas" - a noun.
"žodis" - a noun meaning "word".

"giedmi" - a verb, 1st person sing. with an archaic ending "-mi". Nowadays "giedu" (1st person sing.), "giedoti" (infinitive).

"garbė" - a noun "honour, glory, fame"
"garbinti" - a verb meaning "to worship, adore, glorify". "garbinu" - 1st person sing.
May be it is "geras", an adjective meaning "good".

"godus" - an adjective meaning "greedy".
"gėdu" is an archaic form of a noun meaning "shame".
geriu - 1st person sing.
I do not see a relation between "žaidžiu" (meaning "I play") and the root "gai" (to sing). May be in old Lithuanian it had that meaning.

"grėbiu" - 1st person sing.
"grėbti" - infinitive.
Infinitive form.

"gentis" - a noun meaning "tribe, clan".
"gimtis" - a noun meaning "birth, origin"

"gyvenu" - 1st person sing. "I live".
"gyventi" - infinitive.

"teku" - 1st person sing. "I flow" or "I marry".
"tekėti" - infinitive.

"degu" - 1st person sing.
"degti" - infinitive.
Both equaly used.

There is an archaic word "dyra", a noun meaning "whipping, punishment".
Nowadays we use a verb "drausti" (to forbid, prohibit).
masc. and femin. forms.
1st person sing. and infinitive forms.
1st person sing. and infinitive forms.
Infinitive form.
infinitive.
infinitive.

"patis" is an archaic word and not used anymore.

Interesting thing though that a feminine form "pati" (meaning "a wife") is still used.
1st person sing ("I fart")

Lith. word "pelai" means "chaff" or whatever is left after thrashing grains.   
Or there is another archaic noun that I am not familiar with and  related to measurement.

"palvas" is an archaic word, not used anymore.
There are other word used nowadays "palkšvas" or "pilkšvas" meaning "greyish" or indicates a dull colour.

Lith. "purvas" means "mud, filth, dirt".

Sanskrit "palvala" means "a pool, small tank, pond". There is a Lith.word "prūdas" meaning "a pond, small tank".

"paskui" - adverb.
"paskutinis" - adjective.

It is an archaic form that I cannot identify for sure but here is my guess. 
"peniu" (I nourish) is close to what MW provided and related to sanskrit "pā" (to protect, preserve).
"penėti" (to nourish).
infinitive
prefix
infinitive

All three are archaic. 
Adjective "bėras" might still be used in villages.
 
There is another word in Lithuanian "bebras" ("beaver"). Its colour is  dark brown ("briūnas" (arch.)). And Lith."bebras" is very close to Sanskrit "babhru".

"budėti"- infintive form,
"budrus"- adjective.
bagotas and "nabagas" are antonyms.

infinitive.
The letter "s" at the end makes a verb reflexive.
infinitive.

"blizgu" - adverbial form
"blizgus" - adjective.
"blizgėti" - verb, infinitive.

"broterėlis" is an archaic from which is not used anymore.
Nowadays "brolis" or "brolelis" (diminutive form).

"minėti" given by MW means "to refer, mention, commemorate".

"manyti" (infin.) means "to think, consider, suppose, assume" and is much closer in meaning to sanskrit root "man".
molis (clay) is ok but it is difficult for me to understand how "mėlynas" (blue) relates to sanskrit "mala".

archaic forms. According to lituanists these are barbarisms and shouldn't be used.

But there is a noun "matas" (measure unit) 
or a verb "matuoti" (to measure).

"motė" is an archaic form.
Nowadays "moteris" (woman), "motina" (mother).

"maišyti" (infinitive), "maišau" (1st person sing.)
meaning "to mix, blend".

"mėžti" (to muck, to take dung out) exists but according to the meaning 
"myžti" (to urinate) is much closer to the sanskrit root "mih".
plural form.

"jungas" is a noun.
"jungti" is a verb (infinitive).
1st person sing.

Other examples came to my mind: 
verb "raminti" (to make still, peaceful; to calm down), 
adjective "ramus" (still, quiet, peaceful, calm).

These are adjectives meaning "callous".
Verb "rambėti" (to get or become callous).

"rudis" - looks like an archaic form.
"rauda" - noun (sob, cry).
"raudoti" - verb (infinitive to sob, to cry).
raudas archaic form, not used anymore.

It is an archaic form which is not used anymore. 
Very similar Lithuanian word "atrūgos" means 1. belch, brash eructation; 2. whey.

Lithuanian words for Sanskrit "romantha" nowadays are "atrajojimas, atraja, gromulavimas".

"lengvus", "lungvas" - archaic forms.
Nowadays "lengvas".
Both are nouns.
laižyti - to lick.

This is an old form and I am not sure. These are my guesses.
I. "viešėti" (to stay, to visit)
II. Or a rearly used verb "vėžėti" (1. to drive; 2. to leave track, to rut).

"sausas" (adjective) means "dry".
Other two forms must be archaic. I can't identify them.
It should be "klausyti" (to listen, hear) because "klausti" has a meaning "to ask, inquire".

These are Lith.verbs which are close by the meaning to the Sanskrit root "śvit":
"švytėti" means "to shine, glow, glitter". 
"švyti" - "it glows". 
"šviesti" meaning "to shine, illuminate".
"švisti" meaning "to dawn.

The given form "švailyti" must be archaic.

The given form "spiauju" has archaic ending.
"spjaunu" - 1st pers. sing.
"spjauti" - infinitive.
1st pers. sing.
1st pers. sing.
1st pers. sing.

"sąs"  must be archaic form.
"esąs" , "esantis" - present participles (being, existing).

"sekmas" is archaic form.
Nowadays "septintas".

The given adjective forms "stambras, stimbras" are archaic.
"stambus", "stiprus" are the present forms of those same adjectives.

The given adjective forms "stambras, stimbras" are archaic.
"stambus", "stiprus" are the present forms of those same adjectives.

"steigti" - verb, infinitive form.
"stogas" - noun.

"pulti" has many meanings "to attack, advance", "to fall", "to begin".
"purtyti" (to shake) has a much closer meaning to Sanskrit "sphal".

"sravėti" is an old form.
Nowadays "sruventi" (to flow).
Nowadays "dyvas" is rearly used and has a meaning of "amazing or strange thing" which hardly corresponds to Sanskrit "div".

MW says "Lit. davyti, to torment; ". 
Nowadays a verb "davyti" has a meaning "to catch up". 

I have a wild guess. Keeping in mind that at the end of the XIX century Lithuania was strongly under influence of Russia, many Russian words had been absorbed in local vocabulary. In Russian there is a word "давить" (to press, to oppress). It could be that Lithuanians made a verb "davyti" in the similar sense.

"drįstu" - 1st pers. sing.
"drįsti" - infinitive.

In old Lithuanian (XIX cent.) "pisa" meant "vulva", 
and "pisti" meant "to urinate".

Nowadays these are verbs with vulgar meanings. 
"pisa" - "he fucks"; "pisti" - "to fuck".

Keeping in mind that MW provides Lit. "pautas" after
 
पोत mn. a vessel, ship, boat, MBh. ; Hariv. ; Var. ; Kāv.  [ID=129263]
पोत [cf. Lat. putus; Lit. pautas.] [ID=129263.1]

I think it should be "plaustas" which has a meaning of "a boat, ship, vessel; ferry, float, etc.).

 "pautas" must be an archaic form. 
Nowadays we also have word "pautas" but is rearly used and in a vulgar meaning "balls, nuts, bollokcs".
bendras - adjective.
menturis is an archaic form and it means "a tool-stick for churning butter or grounding porridge".
Archaic form. Not used anymore.

Nowadays a verb "spėti" (to guess, suppose) is not related to "sphāy". 
Looks like an archaic form of some other verb which I cannot recognise.
I have a wild guess. Keeping in mind that at the end of the XIX century Lithuania was strongly under influence of Russia, many Russian words had been absorbed in local vocabulary. In Russian there is a word "спелый" (ripe). It could be that Lithuanians made a verb "spėti" in the sense "to ripen".
A few decades back it was used along with "žansis".
